it.poliba.sisinflab.dlpreferences.tree

Interface BasePreferenceForest<P,S extends java.util.stream.BaseStream<P,S>>

  • Type Parameters:
    P - the type of elements representing propositional variables
    S - a stream type representing a branch
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractPreferenceForest, IntPreferenceForest, PreferenceForest

    public interface BasePreferenceForest<P,S extends java.util.stream.BaseStream<P,S>>
    Base interface for preference forests.

    Given an input set 

    Q = {p1, p2, … pN}
    where each p is a propositional variable of type P, a preference forest is a collection of rooted trees that generates a family of subsets of 
    F = {p1, not(p1), p2, not(p2), … pN, not(pN)}
    At level k < N, the forest generates the k-subsets of F, excluding the ones in which a propositional variable p appears as both p and not(p).

    After the N-th expansion, the forest will be empty.

    The distinctive feature of a preference forest is the ability to control the expansion process by filtering branches. See expand(Predicate) for more information.

    The following snippet shows how to fully expand a forest while retrieving the list of branches at each level: 

    
      while(!forest.isEmpty()) {
          List<S> branches = forest.branches();
          forest.expand();
      }

      A node that stores an element of type P and a reference to its parent.

    • Method Detail

      • branches

        java.util.List<S> branches()
        Returns the list of branches.
        Returns:

      • size

        default int size()
        Returns the number of branches.
        Returns:

      • isEmpty

        default boolean isEmpty()
        Returns true if all branches have been cut.
        Returns:

      • expand

        default void expand()
        Expands each eligible branch by one level. A branch is eligible for expansion if it has not yet reached its maximum length. Ineligible branches are cut from the forest.

        After k invocations of this method on a forest constructed from the propositional variables p1, p2, …, pN, branches() will return the k-subsets of 

        { p1, not(p1), p2, not(p2), …, pN, not(pN) }
        excluding the ones in which a propositional variable p appears as both p and not(p).

        After the N-th and subsequent invocations, isEmpty() will always evaluate to true.

      • expand

        void expand(java.util.function.Predicate<S> branchFilter)
        Inserts a filter in the expansion process of expand(). Branches who do not match input the Predicate become ineligible for expansion.

        This method aims for concurrent processing of the branches. The input Predicate must follow the same behavioral constraints specified by Stream.filter(Predicate).

        Parameters:
        branchFilter - a non-interfering, stateless predicate to apply to each branch of the forest before expansion. If false, the branch is cut from the forest.

      • expand

        void expand(boolean[] mask)
        Inserts a filter in the expansion process of expand(), based on a boolean mask. Branches who map to false become ineligible for expansion.
        Parameters:
        mask -
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if mask does not match the current number of branches.
